org.parboiled
Class BaseParser<V>

java.lang.Object
  org.parboiled.BaseActions<V>
      org.parboiled.BaseParser<V>
Type Parameters:
V - The type of the value field of the parse tree nodes created by this parser.
All Implemented Interfaces:
ContextAware<V>
public abstract class BaseParser<V>
extends BaseActions<V>

Base class for custom parsers. Defines basic methods for rule and action parameter creation.

Nested Class Summary
protected static class BaseParser.IgnoreCaseWrapper
          Wrapper for rule cache keys that are used for explicit "ignore-case matchers"

Method Detail

parse

public ParsingResult<V> parse(Rule rule,
                              @NotNull
                              String input)
Runs the given parser rule against the given input string.

Parameters:
rule - the rule
input - the input string
Returns:
the ParsingResult for the run

ch

public Rule ch(char c)
Explicitly creates a rule matching the given character. Normally you can just specify the character literal directly in you rule description. However, if you want to not go through fromCharLiteral(char), e.g. because you redefined it, you can also use this wrapper.

Parameters:
c - the char to match
Returns:
a new rule

charIgnoreCase

public Rule charIgnoreCase(char c)
Explicitly creates a rule matching the given character ignoring the case.

Parameters:
c - the char to match independently of its case
Returns:
a new rule

charRange

public Rule charRange(char cLow,
                      char cHigh)
Creates a rule matching a range of characters from cLow to cHigh (both inclusively).

Parameters:
cLow - the start char of the range (inclusively)
cHigh - the end char of the range (inclusively)
Returns:
a new rule

string

public Rule string(@NotNull
                   String string)
Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string. Normally you can just specify the string literal directly in you rule description. However, if you want to not go through fromStringLiteral(String), e.g. because you redefined it, you can also use this wrapper.

Parameters:
string - the string to match
Returns:
a new rule

stringIgnoreCase

public Rule stringIgnoreCase(String string)
Explicitly creates a rule matching the given string in a case-independent fashion.

Parameters:
string - the string to match
Returns:
a new rule

firstOf

public Rule firstOf(Object rule,
                    Object rule2,
                    Object... moreRules)
Creates a new rule that successively tries all of the given subrules and succeeds when the first one of its subrules matches. If all subrules fail this rule fails as well.

Parameters:
rule - the first subrule
rule2 - the second subrule
moreRules - the other subrules
Returns:
a new rule

oneOrMore

public Rule oneOrMore(Object rule)
Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of its subrule and succeeds if the subrule matches at least once. If the subrule does not match at least once this rule fails.

Parameters:
rule - the subrule
Returns:
a new rule

optional

public Rule optional(Object rule)
Creates a new rule that tries a match on its subrule and always succeeds, independently of the matching success of its subrule.

Parameters:
rule - the subrule
Returns:
a new rule

sequence

public Rule sequence(Object rule,
                     Object rule2,
                     Object... moreRules)
Creates a new rule that only succeeds if all of its subrule succeed, one after the other.

Parameters:
rule - the first subrule
rule2 - the second subrule
moreRules - the other subrules
Returns:
a new rule

enforcedSequence

public Rule enforcedSequence(Object rule,
                             Object rule2,
                             Object... moreRules)
Creates a new rule that only succeeds if all of its subrules succeed, one after the other. However, after the first subrule has matched all further subrule matches are enforced, i.e. if one of them fails a ParseError will be created (and error recovery will be tried).

Parameters:
rule - the first subrule
rule2 - the second subrule
moreRules - the other subrules
Returns:
a new rule

test

public Rule test(Object rule)
Creates a new rule that acts as a syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the given subrule against the current input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the subrule succeeds and fails if the subrule rails. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create a parse tree node.

Parameters:
rule - the subrule
Returns:
a new rule

testNot

public Rule testNot(Object rule)
Creates a new rule that acts as an inverse syntactic predicate, i.e. tests the given subrule against the current input position without actually matching any characters. Succeeds if the subrule fails and fails if the subrule succeeds. Since this rule does not actually consume any input it will never create a parse tree node.

Parameters:
rule - the subrule
Returns:
a new rule

zeroOrMore

public Rule zeroOrMore(Object rule)
Creates a new rule that tries repeated matches of its subrule. Succeeds always, even if the subrule doesn't match even once.

Parameters:
rule - the subrule
Returns:
a new rule

eoi

public Rule eoi()
Matches the EOI (end of input) character.

Returns:
a new rule

any

public Rule any()
Matches any character except Chars.EOI.

Returns:
a new rule

empty

public Rule empty()
Matches nothing and therefore always succeeds.

Returns:
a new rule

UP

public final <T> T UP(T argument)
Changes the context scope of all arguments to the current parent scope.

Parameters:
argument - the arguments to change to context for
Returns:
the result of the argument

DOWN

public final <T> T DOWN(T argument)
Changes the context scope of all arguments to the current sub scope. This will only work if this call is at some level wrapped with one or more UP(Object) calls, since the default scope is always at the bottom of the context chain.

Parameters:
argument - the arguments to change to context for
Returns:
the result of the argument

fromCharLiteral

protected Rule fromCharLiteral(char c)
Used internally to convert the given character literal to a parser rule. You can override this method, e.g. for specifying a sequence that automatically matches all trailing whitespace after the character.

Parameters:
c - the character
Returns:
the rule

fromStringLiteral

protected Rule fromStringLiteral(String string)
Used internally to convert the given string literal to a parser rule. You can override this method, e.g. for specifying a sequence that automatically matches all trailing whitespace after the string.

Parameters:
string - the string
Returns:
the rule

cached

protected Rule cached(Object key)
Returns the rule cache content for the given key.

Parameters:
key - the cache key
Returns:
the cached rule or null

cache

protected Rule cache(Object key,
                     Rule rule)
Caches the given rule in the rule cache under the given key and return the rule.

Parameters:
key - the key to store the rule under in the cache
rule - the rule to cache
Returns:
the rule

toRules

protected Rule[] toRules(@NotNull
                         Object[] objects)
Converts the given object array to an array of rules.

Parameters:
objects - the objects to convert
Returns:
the rules corresponding to the given objects

toRule

protected Rule toRule(Object obj)
Converts the given object to a rule.

Parameters:
obj - the object to convert
Returns:
the rule corresponding to the given object

fromUserObject

protected Rule fromUserObject(Object obj)
Attempts to convert the given object into a rule. Override this method in order to be able to use custom objects directly in your rule specification. The method should return null if the given object cannot be converted into a rule (which is all the default implementation does). Note that the results are automatically cached, so the method is never called twice for equal objects.

Parameters:
obj - the object to convert
Returns:
the rule for the object or null
